title: ISic003324. Two dedications to a Caesar by the Annii
body:
1P(ublius) · (scil. et) M(arcus) · Anniei · P(ubli) · f(ilii)
2Vot(uria tribu)
3Caesaris · filio
1P(ublius) · (scil. et) M(arcus) · Anniei · P(ubli) · f(ilii)
2Vot(uria tribu)
3C(aio) · Caesari · August(i) · f(ilio)

1P(scil. ET)MANNIEIPF
2VOT
3CAESARISFILIO
1P(scil. ET)MANNIEIPF
2VOT
3CCAESARIAUGUSTF

Facsimile Images

Apparatus criticus

  • Text from autopsy

English translation

Jonathan Prag

Publius and Marcus Annii, of the tribe Voturia, (set this up) to the son of Caesar / Publius and Marcus Annii, of the tribe Voturia, (set this up) to Caius Caesar, son of Augustus

commentary

The exact explanation for this double dedication remains uncertain. Battistoni and Rothenöfer speculate that the possibly earlier inscription of Text A could have been a dedication to Octavian as son of Caesar, but reject this as somewhat unlikely and prefer the hypothesis that both inscriptions are dedications to Caius Caesar, the grandson and adopted son of Augustus, with Text A containing an erroneous first text which fails to use the correct onomastic formula for Caius. The Annii were a significant family in Agrigento, with involvement in the sulphur industry.

bibliography

  • De Miro 1984-1985 464-465 tav.34.1 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10002053
  • Manganaro 1988 26, 47 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10001427
  • De Miro 2000 381 fig. 6 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10002051
  • Pugliese Carratelli and Fiorentini 1992 107-108 ph https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10001649
  • Battistoni and Rothenöfer 2012 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10002663
  • Manganaro 2013 249-252 fig.2-4 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10001789
  • Zambito 2013-2014 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10001502
